title: Looup rt and parameters
body:
I think that rt is not an attribute of a registration; the first commit reflects that. (The second is more bycatch from that).

Possibly we can simplify the whole section; as everything in the result is links, we're only applying the same link filtering that 6690 already specifies (plus pagination).

title: ER, modelling semantics: Changes to the model itself
body:
This is the first step to closing [54], doing the changes to the model itself.

Won't close the issue by itself probably, as some other portions might mention the model.

This does not try to address any of the open issues.

[54]: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/54

title: 5988-vs-6690-anchors: Initial text for siding with 5988
body:
If the WG decides to use the clarified 5988 semantics for href resolution[1], then this is a starting text.

No attempts have been made here to clean up the terminology, this is only about the statements about what affects what, and is an update to the examples.

The last record in the example has been changed to be illustrative with the new behavior.

[1]: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/12u9QBS6q5v5IYknKl_bJYhJKrI

---

I'm phrasing this as a pull request so it is easily accessible to RD contributors; I don't expect this to be merged right away.

title: Link model clarifications (mainly con=)
body:
This is the documenting text to the changes worked out first on the examples in #45.

It does not (yet) contain explaining overall text, but updates the various smaller mentions of the `con` parameter to fit together. It does change the semantics of using `con` on a registration update, but I believe that the previous wording was not what the original authors had intended. (Previously, an endpoint registering over TCP would need to explicitly repeat its con on every update).

title: Fixes for the idnits checker
body:
I've had to override the commit-time check for [idnits](https://tools.ietf.org/tools/idnits/) recently; these edits make the document idnits clean again.

I don't expect much controversy over those, but @petervanderstok, are you OK with labelling scheme://host:port as "con" in the diagram? (As it was, it's too wide for an RFC).

title: [examples first] Do URI resolution via anchor instead of href
body:
These changes were talked about previously in Prague and allow preservation of link relationships.

A new example based on the relevant RFC6690 example shows different relevant cases (with `anchor=` present in the registration) in the lookup interface.

The latest suggestions of bringing the endpoint interface in line with that are not included yet.

title: Registration: drop lifetime "most recently supplied value re-use"
body:
The mechanism is useful in updates, but at the registration interface
they do not make sense.

Closes: https://github.com/core-wg/resource-directory/issues/33

title: lookup: Mention Observe for continuous interest
body:
Observe, ETag and possible future mechanisms are stated to be generally
usable, but phrased as a "like with any other resource", because there
is no need to actually define something new here.

title: Drop "base URI" references
body:
All URIs of RD APIs are discovered standalone, and no relative URI or path-appending is required any more. Therefore, the term "Base URIs" and the distinction between "rd-lookup-base" and "lookup-type" in the RD lookup API are obsolete.

This has already been [mentioned on the mailing list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/7zzSmZK6Od1Rw3vzpaenN4G6otw), and [acked by Peter](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/core/NCLNlY8N__TCf9UMEq5yF1WxSJs), if I understood his response correctly (which I'm unsure about, thus tagging this for review).

title: Restore ins=/exp=
body:
These commits restore the ins=/exp= definitions dropped after -09, and instead of referencing the DNS-SD mapping chapter, reference the (so far not even uploaded) RD-DNS-SD draft.

There is some confusion between where arguments can be used, but the "what goes where" of the link-format attributes is a separate issue to be tackled.
